The recommended first-line medication for the treatment of ulcerative colitis is aminosalicylates, which work by inhibiting leukotriene synthesis and lipoxygenase, thus reducing inflammation in the colon. Suppression of cellular and humoral immunity is a mechanism of action for immunosuppressive agents used in the treatment of UC, but it is not the first-line medication. Inhibition of enzyme phospholipase A2 is a mechanism of action for corticosteroids used in the treatment of UC, but also not the first-line medication. Cross-linking of DNA of bacteria causing UC is a mechanism of action for antibiotics, which may be used in the treatment of bacterial infections associated with UC, but not as the first-line medication for UC itself.

The first-line medication for UC is typically a 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) derivative such as mesalamine. These drugs act by inhibiting leukotriene synthesis and lipoxygenase, which in turn reduces inflammation in the colon.
